posts.name: mbhoxsie
posts.cooked:
What is the best way that teams have found this season for calculating the Standard Deviations for the SetVisionMeasurementStdDevs for field localization?

Our team is using Limelights and a CTRE generated swerve drive.   We’ve taken the sample code from CTRE as well as Limelight’s Megatag2 documentation.    Now all that’s left is trying to calibrate it to optimize  our autons and speed up our the Auto Align that we are already doing for the Reef and Human Player Stations.

Below is a clip of our Java code from robotPeriodic()…

Any suggestions would be greatly appreciated!

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
This was recently tossed around the discord server too.

One “real” way - measure your x/y/rotation signals coming from the camera, plot them out in AdvantageScope (et. al.) and then calculate the standard deviation of the noise in the signal.

Do this stationary to start - assume the mean of the error is zero, and any deviation from that is noise. Try at a few different distances and angles to see how the std dev changes with respect to these. Pick either the average, the worst, or something dynamic based on where you’re at on the field.

Even more complex, have some way to get a “ground truth” measurement you trust - some other good sensor, probably… and measure your error against that. Same process as above, repeat in many scenarios to see how the std. dev of the error changes with respect to distance/angle to target.

Alternatively, go the opposite way: just keep guessing till your pose convergence “feels” reasonable. The smaller std. dev. you provide, the faster the estimated pose converges to the vision estimate. Just tune/tweak this till you feel like your noise in your measurement is filtered out enough, and you’re not drastically reacting to a bad measurement.

Up to you how to proceed. No shame in using vibes in a case like FRC . Though I might shame you if you use vibes while designing the car I paid $50k for.

link_counts.title: Question regarding standard deviations in vision measurements

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
As far as I understand, it’s the way the youths describe “using your feelings and intuition to make technical decisions despite the lack of data”. Which is fraught, especially when the decisions have big implications, or when the people making the decisions don’t have enough time “behind the wheel” for their feelings to be meaningful.

I am no longer a youth, I merely appropriate their language in an attempt to communicate. Hopefully with mild success.

posts.name: Nolan Barker
posts.cooked:
We used a heuristic-backed system (heavy on the heuristics) to dynamically adjust standard devs for each post estimate.

We did not use the method setVisionMeasurementStdDevs() because it meant that we had to provide one “trust” in vision for all estimates. However, not all estimates are equal in quality and we wanted our code to reflect this. Instead, (assuming we’re talking CTRE ) you can simply pass in a matrix along with the estimate each time you supply a pose estimate . This lets you pick and choose which estimates are more trustworthy.

I considered doing what @gerthworm mentioned with measuring the actual std dev through testing, but we didn’t have enough time with the robot this year for that to be very reasonable. So, I used my imagination and with some magic hand-waving, I arrived at a solution that worked really well - way better than I could have hoped.

What my team ended up doing is basically using the following algorithm to determine a “standard deviation multiplier” that we use to scale a default value (around 10cm of standard deviation). This multiplier is computed for each measurement, rather than using a single std. deviation for each.

Here’s the breakdown of all the heuristics we used:

We scaled std devs up proportionally to the average distance to all seen tag (but made no change if that value fell within a certain “trusty” range. Further tags are less likely to be as accurate as tags closer to the camera.

We scaled std devs up with higher ambiguity poses because they’re more likely to be wrong.

We scaled std devs up proportionally to the distance between that pose estimate and the most recent known position). If we get a couple seemingly “accurate” pose estimates that come from across the field, they are effectively discarded because this has such a high proportionality constant.

We scaled std devs up proportionally to the latency that the result came in. We adjust timestamps for latency compensation before passing them to the Kalman Filter, but we magnify this effect by also increasing std devs. Probably isn’t necessary.

We scaled std devs inversely proportionally to the number of tags that we see. For example, a pose estimate that sees two reef tags is much more viable than an estimate that only sees one. This was for two reasons: not only does the multitag algorithm seem super accurate, but a single-tag result is subject to ambiguity to an extremely higher extent (don’t quote me on this, but I don’t think ambiguity is a thing when you have multiple tags in frame).

Each of these factors gets their own unique weights and shifts to fine-tune our vision system just right , and after about an hour of guessing numbers and tweaking values, our pose estimates were both stable and highly accurate.

For example: we ran very low-resolution cameras, which seemed to mean at further distances, pose estimates became highly unstable. However, we were able to dynamically counteract this because as we are further away from the tag(s), we trusted those estimates less.

link_counts.title: Best tutorial on using photonvision with swerve drive to drive to apriltags

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
therekrab:

our pose estimates were both stable and highly accurate

How do you determine accuracy for a robot that is moving and what robot velocities did you use?

therekrab:

adjust timestamps for latency compensation

Does your latency adjustment vary with the robot velocity?

posts.name: Nolan Barker
posts.cooked:
Velocity compensation is a feature that I’ve been interested in addressing but I haven’t gotten around to working on it. Currently it’s not really a problem because we slow down as we score so such a difference isn’t noticeable. Also we run low reaolution cameras (240x320) so we get a LOT of estimates so by the time that old pose estimates are wrong enough we’ve gotten maybe 200 more (4 cameras running 100fps for half a second) so any new estimates are already in.

So we don’t directly address it. :(. But it hasn’t been a very crucial issue. But I still want to answer your question in a less boring way. What I would do is probably descale the difference multiplier (distance from last pose) proportionally to velocity. This would tell it to trust further poses when we’re going faster. Probably not a major change but finding that constant of proportionality that does what we want takes time. After getting that working, I’d next add a feature that changes that behavior a little to add trust for poses that would show movement in the same direction the robot is moving and trust less the poses that are traveling in the “wrong direction”. But it’s still in the design phase.
